title: Celanda batik tulis (man’s pyjama pants)

  object_colour: multicolored

  physical_appearance: This is a pair of batik pants. It has a symmetrical pattern of tendril-like blue flowering stems
 against a background of diagonal rows of black wavy lines. The rows of black lines are alternated with blue borders of white diamond-shaped motifs. The bottom of the pants are bordered my floral patterns on a blue background.

  subject_terms_1: flowers (motifs) Peranakan lozenges cultural diffusion

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Culture diffusion Peranakan (Asian people) Batik Pajamas

  subject_terms_3: Batik

  sgcool_label_text: This pair of batik pants contains a symmetrical pattern of tendril-like blue flowering stems.  They are set against a background of diagonal rows of black wavy lines that are framed by blue borders of white diamond-shaped motifs.  The batik cloth is carefully cut and joined in the middle to produce the symmetry of pattern.  Beginning in the 19th century
 batik was used to produce tailored garments.  For European men
 batik pyjama (celanda) trousers and sarong (for informal wear) became common as the Europeans adapted to the weather and lifestyle in Southeast Asia.  Children’s celanda were often tailored from used adult batik.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a pair of batik pants. It has a symmetrical pattern of tendril-like blue flowering stems, against a background of diagonal rows of black wavy lines. The rows of black lines are alternated with blue borders of white diamond-shaped motifs. The bottom of the pants are bordered my floral patterns on a blue background.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Culture diffusion Peranakan (Asian people) Batik Pajamas
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This pair of batik pants contains a symmetrical pattern of tendril-like blue flowering stems.  They are set against a background of diagonal rows of black wavy lines that are framed by blue borders of white diamond-shaped motifs.  The batik cloth is carefully cut and joined in the middle to produce the symmetry of pattern.  Beginning in the 19th century, batik was used to produce tailored garments.  For European men, batik pyjama (celanda) trousers and sarong (for informal wear) became common as the Europeans adapted to the weather and lifestyle in Southeast Asia.  Children’s celanda were often tailored from used adult batik.
